Testo originario: Nucer(i)<ae=EA> quaeres ad porta(m) Romana(m) / in vico Venerio Novelliam / Primigeniam
Traduzione ENG: At Nuceria, look for Novellia Primigenia near the Roman gate in the prostitute’s district.
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Luogo: Casa e Ufficio di Volusius Iuvencus
Testo originario: Secundus / Prim(a)e suae ubi/que i<p=S>s(a)e salute(m) rogo domina / ut me ames
Traduzione ENG: Secundus says hello to his Prima, wherever she is. I ask, my mistress, that you love me.
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: Miximus in lecto fateor peccavimus hospes / si dices quare nulla matella fuit
Traduzione ENG: We have wet the bed, host. I confess we have done wrong. If you want to know why, there was no chamber pot
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: Successus textor amat coponiaes(!) ancilla(m) / nomine Hiredem quae quidem illum / non curat sed illa com(m)iseretur / scribit rivalis vale / invidiose quia rumper<i=E>s se<c=D>are noli formonsiorem // et qui est homo prav<i=E>ssimus et bellus
Traduzione ENG: The story of Successus, Severus and Iris is played out on the walls of a bar: [Severus]: “Successus, a weaver, loves the innkeeper’s slave girl named Iris. She, however, does not love him. Still, he begs her to have pity on him. His rival wrote this. Goodbye.”. [Answer by Successus]: “Envious one, why do you get in the way. Submit to a handsomer man and one who is being treated very wrongly and good looking.” [Answer by Severus]: “I have spoken. I have written all there is to say. You love Iris, but she does not love you.”
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: Dixi scripsi amas Hiredem / quae te non curat SIX() Successo / ut su[p]ra(t) [3]s[3] / Severus
Traduzione ENG: The story of Successus, Severus and Iris is played out on the walls of a bar: [Severus]: “Successus, a weaver, loves the innkeeper’s slave girl named Iris. She, however, does not love him. Still, he begs her to have pity on him. His rival wrote this. Goodbye.”. [Answer by Successus]: “Envious one, why do you get in the way. Submit to a handsomer man and one who is being treated very wrongly and good looking.” [Answer by Severus]: “I have spoken. I have written all there is to say. You love Iris, but she does not love you.”
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: Quisquis amat veniat Veneri volo frangere costas / fustibus et lumbos debilitare deae / si potest illa mihi tenerum pertundere pectus / quit ego non possim caput i[ll]ae frangere fuste
Traduzione ENG: Let everyone one in love come and see. I want to break Venus’ ribs with clubs and cripple the goddess’ loins. If she can strike through my soft chest, then why can’t I smash her head with a club?
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: Pyrrhus Chio co<l=N>legae sal(utem) / moleste fero quod audivi / te mortu<u=O>m itaqe val(e)
Traduzione ENG: Pyrrhus to his colleague Chius: I grieve because I hear you have died; and so farewell.
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: Amoris ignes sentires mulio / magi(s) properares ut videres Venerem / diligo puerum venustum rogo punge iamus / bibisti iamus prende lora et excute / Pompeios defer ubi dulcis est amor / meus es
Traduzione ENG: If you felt the fires of love, mule-driver, you would make more haste to see Venus. I love a charming boy; I ask you, goad the mules; let’s go. Take me to Pompeii, where love is sweet. You are mine…
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: Amantes ut apes vita(m) mellita(m) exigunt
Traduzione ENG: Lovers are like bees in that they live a honeyed life
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: L(ucius) Istacidi(us) a<d=T> quem non ceno barbarus ille mihi est
Traduzione ENG: Lucius Istacidius, I regard as a stranger anyone who doesn’t invite me to dinner.
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Testo originario: (Quis)quis amat valeat pereat qui nescit amare / bis tanto pereat quisquis amare vetat
Traduzione ENG: Whoever loves, let him flourish. Let him perish who knows not love. Let him perish twice over whoever forbids love.
ATTRIBUTIONS: By Fer.filol (Own work) [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons

Luogo: Negozio di ceramica o Bar di Nicanor
Testo originario: Lesbiane cacas scribisque [sa]lute(m)
Traduzione ENG: Lesbianus, you defecate and you write, ‘Hello, everyone!’

Testo originario: ] dolete puellae / p(a)edi[care volo] cunne superbe va(le) / Ampliatus toties / [3] scribet toties venit / hoc quoque futu{tu}i futui / car<d=B>ine negate[3] locoru(m) car / hic / recareas meo [3] / ara
Traduzione ENG: Weep, you girls. My penis has given you up. Now it penetrates men’s behinds. Goodbye, wondrous femininity!

Testo originario: Restutus / Restetuta / pone tunica(m) / rogo red(d)es / pilosa(m) c<u=O>(nnum)
Traduzione ENG: Restitutus says: “Restituta, take off your tunic, please, and show us your hairy privates”.

Testo originario: Amplicate / Icarus / te pedicat / Salvius / scripsit
Traduzione ENG: Amplicatus, I know that Icarus is buggering you. Salvius wrote this.
Descrizione: sotto di un disegno di un uomo con un grande naso

Testo originario: Cicuta ab rationibus // Neronis Augusti
Traduzione ENG: The finances officer of the emperor Nero says this food is poison

Testo originario: Hic fuimus cari duo nos sine fine sodales / nomina si [quaeris Caius et Aulus erant]
Traduzione ENG: We two dear men, friends forever, were here. If you want to know our names, they are Gaius and Aulus.

Testo originario: Roma / olim / miro / amor
III Non(as) Septe(mbres) / Satura [fuit(?)] hic
Traduzione ENG: Satura was here on September 3rd

Testo originario: Futui / coponam
Traduzione ENG: I screwed the barmaid

Testo originario: Pamhira si[t]ifera
Traduzione ENG: Palmyra, the thirst-quencher

Testo originario: Floronius / binet ac miles / leg(ionis) VII hic / fuit neque / mulieres / scierunt nisi / paucae et / se<x=S> erunt
Traduzione ENG: Floronius, privileged soldier of the 7th legion, was here. The women did not know of his presence. Only six women came to know, too few for such a stallion.

Testo originario: M() Sita(?)
Traduzione ENG: On April 19th, I made bread ?

Testo originario: Antiochus / hic mansit / cum sua / Cithera
Traduzione ENG: Antiochus hung out here with his girlfriend Cithera.

Traduzione ITA: L'acqua lavi i piedi e, lavati, uno schiavo li asciughi; una tovaglia ricopra il letto; non sporcare la nostra biancheria di lino
Traduzione ENG: Let water wash your feet clean and a slave wipe them dry; let a cloth cover the couch; take care of our linens.

Traduzione ITA: Evita di fare espressioni cupide e occhiuzzi languidi alla moglie altrui; la tua bocca conservi il pudore.
Traduzione ENG: Remove lustful expressions and flirtatious tender eyes from another man’s wife; may there be modesty in your expression.

Traduzione ITA: Evita i contrasti e rinvia gli odiosi litigi, se puoi, altrimenti, esci e tornatene a casa tua
Traduzione ENG: […]postpone your tiresome quarrels if you can, or leave and take them home with you.
To the one defecating here. Beware of the curse. If you look down on this curse, may you have an angry Jupiter for an enemy.

Testo originario: T(h)iop(h)ilus(!) canis / cunnu(m) lingere no/li puellis in muro
Traduzione ENG: Theophilus, don’t perform oral sex on girls against the city wall like a dog
Gaius Sabinus says a fond hello to Statius. Traveler, you eat bread in Pompeii but you go to Nuceria to drink. At Nuceria, the drinking is better.

Luogo: Casa di Valerius Flaccus e di  Valerius Rufinus
Traduzione ENG: Daphnus was here with his Felicla.
Staphylus was here with Quieta.
Aufidius was here. Goodbye
Defecator, may everything turn out okay so that you can leave this place
Marcus loves Spendusa
Celadus the Thracian gladiator is the delight of all the girls
Publius Comicius Restitutus stood right here with his brother

The city block of the Arrii Pollii in the possession of Gnaeus Alleius Nigidius Maius is available to rent from July 1st. There are shops on the first floor, upper stories, high-class rooms and a house. A person interested in renting this property should contact Primus, the slave of Gnaeus Alleius Nigidius Maius.
On April 20th, I gave a cloak to be washed. On May 7th, a headband. On May 8th, two tunics

Luogo: Casa di Sextus Pompeius Axiochus e Julia Helena
Traduzione ENG: Hectice, baby, Mercator says hello to you
Cruel Lalagus, why do you not love me?
I have buggered men

In one bar, a picture depicts two men playing dice. One shouts, “Six!” while his opponent holds up two fingers and says, “No, that’s not a ‘three’; it’s a ‘two’”. By the door of the bar, another picture shows a short man driving a group of men out. Above his head are the words, “Go on, get out of here! You have been fighting!”
Whoever wants to serve themselves can go on an drink from the sea.
What a lot of tricks you use to deceive, innkeeper. You sell water but drink unmixed wine
Blondie has taught me to hate dark-haired girls. I shall hat them, if I can, but I wouldn’t mind loving them. Pompeian Venus Fisica wrote this.

Luogo: Casa di Caesius Valens e Herennius Nardus
Traduzione ENG: Rufus loves Cornelia Hele
If anyone does not believe in Venus, they should gaze at my girl friend
Romula hung out here with Staphylus.

Luogo: Casa Caesius Blandus; nel peristilio della casa di Marte e Venere
Traduzione ENG: It took 640 paces to walk back and forth between here and there ten times
May Love burn in some lonely mountains whoever wants to rape my girl friend!
Atimetus got me pregnant
Figulus loves Idaia
Hedone says, “You can get a drink here for only one coin. You can drink better wine for two coins. You can drink Falernian for four coins.”
I don’t want to sell my husband, not for all the gold in the world
Crescens is sweet and charming
Secundus likes to screw boys.
I screwed a lot of girls here.
On June 15th, Hermeros screwed here with Phileterus and Caphisus.
Sollemnes, you screw well!
Gaius Valerius Venustus, soldier of the 1st praetorian cohort, in the century of Rufus, screwer of women
Vibius Restitutus slept here alone and missed his darling Urbana
The warmest hello to Saenecio Fortunaus, wherever he may go.
Secundus says hello to his friends.
Methe, slave of Cominia, from Atella, loves Chrestus. May Pompeian Venus be dear to both of them and may they always live in harmony.
A copper pot went missing from my shop. Anyone who returns it to me will be given 65 bronze coins (sestertii). 20 more will be given for information leading to the capture of the thief.
If anyone sits here, let him read this first of all: if anyone wants a screw, he should look for Attice; she costs 4 sestertii.
No young buck is complete until he has fallen in love
Auge loves Allotenus
A small problem gets larger if you ignore it
Caesius faithfully loves M[…name lost]
Epaphra, you are bald!
Chie, I hope your hemorrhoids rub together so much that they hurt worse than when they every have before!
Phileros is a eunuch!

If you are able, but not willing, why do you put off our joy and kindle hope and tell me always to come back tomorrow. So, force me to die since you force me to live without you. Your gift will be to stop torturing me. Certainly, hope returns to the lover what it has once snatched away.
Gaius Pumidius Dipilus was here on October 3rd 78 BC.
Take hold of your servant girl whenever you want to; it’s your right
Samius to Cornelius: go hang yourself!
Virgula to her friend Tertius: you are disgusting!
The one who buggers a fire burns his penis
O walls, you have held up so much tedious graffiti that I am amazed that you have not already collapsed in ruin.
Epaphra is not good at ball games.
Love dictates to me as I write and Cupid shows me the way, but may I die if god should wish me to go on without you
Sarra, you are not being very nice, leaving me all alone like this
Stronius Stronnius knows nothing!

Luogo: Casa di  Curvius Marcellus e Fabia
Traduzione ENG: Ampliatus Pedania is a thief!
Learn this: while I am alive, you, hateful death, are coming.
My lusty son, with how many women have you had sexual relations?
“Secundus defecated here” three time on one wall.
Once you are dead, you are nothing
Restitutus has deceived many girls.
